medical_history.chief_complaint: Joint pain and hyperalgesia related to intake of pyridostigmine bromide in a patient with myasthenia gravis.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient started experiencing joint pain and hyperalgesia in 2000, which became more pronounced with further intake of pyridostigmine bromide. Pain typically started gradually in the morning, peaked in the evening, and disappeared at night, with moderate exercise increasing joint pain. After skipping pyridostigmine for 24 hours, pain almost entirely resolved, only to recur upon resuming the medication. Pain improved as the dose was reduced, disappearing after stopping pyridostigmine entirely.
medical_history.past_medical_history: The patient was diagnosed with myasthenia gravis in 1992 and underwent trans-sternal thymectomy. Previous antiepileptic medications caused adverse reactions, and she has a history of respiratory infections.
